  <div id="bodyColumn"> 
   <div id="contentBox"> 
    <!-- The body of the document contains a number of sections --> 
    <div class="section"> 
     <h2>About<a name="About"></a></h2> JOptimizer is an open source library implemented in pure java programming language that addresses the solution of a minimization problem with equality and inequality constraints, 
     <p style="margin-left: 20px; margin-right: 0px"> &nbsp;&nbsp;minimize<sub>x</sub>&nbsp;f<sub>0</sub>(x)&nbsp;&nbsp;s.t. <br> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;f<sub>i</sub>(x) ? 0,&nbsp;&nbsp;i=1,...,m <br> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Ax = b,&nbsp;&nbsp; </p> 
     <p> where f<sub>0</sub>,...,f<sub>m</sub>: <b>R</b><sup>n</sup>?<b>R</b> are convex and twice continuously differentiable multivariate real functions, and A ? <b>R</b><sup>pXn</sup> with <b>rank</b>A = p &lt; n. <br>This is given the name of <i>convex optimization</i> and, for example, LP, QP, QCQP, SOCP, SDP are special cases of it. </p> 
     <p> JOptimizer is thread-safe and can be used in a standalone application as well as in a J2EE environment: in fact, one of its first goals is to fill the lack of a pure-java optimizer because many of the market libraries run in an external process and that's not always a choice (especially in the case it has to be deployed in a J2EE server environment). <br>Internal linear algebra is based on the open source libraries <a class="externalLink" href="http://commons.apache.org/math/">commons-math</a> and <a class="externalLink" href="http://acs.lbl.gov/software/colt/">Colt</a>, while theoretical foundation is based on the work of S.Boyd and L.Vandenberghe, <a class="externalLink" href="http://www.stanford.edu/~boyd/cvxbook/">"Convex Optimization"</a>. </p> 
     <!-- in addition to XHTML, any number of subsections can be within a section
      <subsection name="subsection 1">
        <p>Subsection!</p>
        <p>
          <sup>sup</sup>f(x)
          <sub>sub</sub>
        </p>
      </subsection> --> 
     <br>You can also use JOptimizer for solving not-convex problems in the form of: 
     <p style="margin-left: 20px; margin-right: 0px"> &nbsp;&nbsp;minimize<sub>x</sub>&nbsp;c<sup>T</sup>x&nbsp;&nbsp;s.t. <br> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gx ? h <br> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Ax = b,&nbsp;&nbsp; </p> 
     <p> where G ? <b>R</b><sup>mXn</sup> (or <b>Z</b><sup>mXn</sup>) ,A ? <b>R</b><sup>pXn</sup> (or <b>Z</b><sup>pXn</sup>) and x in {0,1}<sup>n</sup> <br>This is given the name of <i>Binary Integer Programming (BIP)</i>. </p> 
     <br> 
     <dl> 
      <dt>
       NOTE
      </dt> 
      <dd>
       Use of 
       <a class="externalLink" href="http://commons.apache.org/math/">commons-math</a> and 
       <a class="externalLink" href="http://acs.lbl.gov/software/colt/">Colt</a> is only restricted at the internal level of JOptimizer and you as a user don't have to learn these APIs in order to adopt it. Client code can be written in whatever (if any) linear algebra API, in the "test" source folder you can find code examples with 
       <a class="externalLink" href="http://commons.apache.org/math/">commons-math</a> and 
       <a class="externalLink" href="http://acs.lbl.gov/software/colt/">Colt</a> (along with only standard JSE API examples). 
      </dd> 
     </dl> 
     <!-- dl>
        <dt>NOTE 2</dt>
        <dd>Please note that JOptimizer is a general purpose library,
      in the sense that it does not exploit any special structure
      of the problem (at least at a very high level with an appropriate choice
      of the class for the functions involved): in many cases it might be
      necessary to deep leverage the structure of the problem in order to
      increase the precision and the speed of the solution. You can do this via
      an ad-hoc extension of the library classes, or feel free to contact us at
      <a href="mailto:info@joptimizer.com">info@joptimizer.com</a>.
        </dd>
      </dl --> 
     <br>
     <br>
     <br>
